definition: The part of the economy that involves the extraction and harvesting of natural resources, such as agriculture and fishing.
Growing crops intended for industrial use, not just for food.
Crops grown specifically to feed domestic livestock.
The care, cultivation, and breeding of crops and animals.
The practice of raising cattle to produce milk, cheese, butter, and other dairy products.
The art or practice of garden cultivation and management, specifically of fruits and vegetables.
The practice of rotating different crops in and out of a particular planting area in sequential seasons to manage soil fertility and help control pests and diseases.
Man-made substances added to the soil to enhance its fertility and boost crop production, such as ash from soap-boilers.
The process of creating new land from oceans, seas, riverbeds, or lake beds. In the context of the article, this refers to the Dutch efforts to convert wetlands into usable agricultural land.
A historical region in Holland, known for its large-scale land reclamation projects.
Payments made regularly by tenants to landlords for the use of land or property.
